title: Managing Your HIV Meds

content: A large part of life with HIV is managing your medical care. And a big part of that is figuring out all things related to taking your meds. There’s a learning curve to understanding how it all works.

One of the first things you’re tasked with doing is seeing an infectious disease specialist in order to assess your health and how HIV may be progressing in your body. A lot of information and terminology comes at you that might be unfamiliar.

Learning the purpose of routine blood work (labs) and understanding your CD4 count, viral load, and the function of your vital organs are important. The good news is that once you’ve found a good fit with doctors and other health care providers, asking questions and getting useful information gets easier. That can help you even more down the road as you start antiretroviral therapy (ART).

Although it can be overwhelming and intimidating at first, the work you do to start treatment is extremely important. There’s a lot to learn. It’s another reason why having a good relationship with your care team is helpful. As you understand how it all works, you’re more able to make informed decisions about your medical care.

content: The time for me to begin treatment came almost three years after my diagnosis. It was jarring for me because I was settling into a feeling of normalcy with HIV. But by that point, after much trial and error, I felt better equipped to handle everything.

I found a doctor who was well-informed, patient, and who took time to explain everything to me in detail. Figuring out which medication to choose can feel daunting, but it’s a gateway to more balance and stability in the management of your HIV care.

What comes next is usually the most challenging part – actually taking your meds and waiting to see if there are any side effects. When I began treatment, my doctor mildly cautioned me that I’d likely have some minor side effects. I did, but they soon subsided.

content: And although everyone’s experience is different regarding side effects, preparing yourself for them is wise.

Treatment adherence is important to consider also. Developing a routine for taking your meds works wonders. This varies, and your best routine depends on your schedule and habits. But it’s good to find one that suits your life so you can take your meds consistently and not be slowed down by potential side effects.

content: When it comes to making sure you stay on schedule, identify what time of the day is best to take your meds. Some people have little or no side effects. But for others, timing is key.

For example, in the early years of my medication journey, I took Atripla. Even when I took it before going to bed, I felt groggy when I woke up in the morning. Sometimes I forgot to take it before bed, so I took it in the morning. That meant I felt the sleepiest throughout my day at work, making it extremely difficult to function. I share this because it’s one of many examples of trial and error in learning what works best.
The road of taking HIV meds can have some speed bumps, but’s totally doable to figure it all out and find a manageable routine. Then the rest will fall into place.

Making a workable medication plan can mean the difference between a smooth or rocky experience. It’s intimidating at first. But with patience, willingness, and attention to detail, taking your meds consistently and successfully becomes one less thing to worry about.

content: Taking ART to ultimately suppress HIV in your body is important. Once you’ve achieved that goal and you’re undetectable, the rest is smooth sailing.
